titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Collection of Theses from the Faculty of Arts and Science, Department of Economics MC 119
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Darren W. Johnson in 1989. Revised by Caroline Moseley in 1990. Additional description in 2014 by Connor Gaudet.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-12-18T10:52-0500

did.unittitle: Collection of Masters Theses from the Faculty of Arts and Science, Department of Economics
did.physloc: This collection is located in offsite storage. Please contact the repository for access.
did.abstract: This collection contains a selection of masters theses written by students from the Department of Economics between 1971 and 1979.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: New York University. Department of Economics.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Some materials may be restricted. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
New York University Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2641
Fax: (212) 995-4225
E-mail: university-archives@nyu.edu

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials were arranged chronologically at the time of accession. They are currently arranged by year and, within each year, alphabetically by the last name of the author. A list of thesis authors and titles may be found at the Archives. Each box is labeled with the year(s) and the range of first letters of authors' last names in that box. For example: 1971-1973, A-F.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: These materials were accessioned on February 26, 1985, and donated by Emily Rizzo, a staff member in the Department of Economics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains a selection of masters theses written by students from the Department of Economics between 1971 and 1979. A full list of thesis authors and titles may be found at the Archives. This collection does not contain all graduate theses written by students but is, rather, a selection that was collected by the Department during this time period.

bioghist.head: History of the Economics Department
bioghist.p: Undergraduate courses in Political Economy and Finance were being offered at NYU as early as 1846 as part of the Political Science Department's curriculum. In 1895, Political Economy and Finance professor Frank M. Colby became the sole faculty member of the newly formed Graduate School Department of Economics. Undergraduate courses in economics continued to be offered solely by the Department of Political Science until 1912, when an undergraduate Department of Economics was established.

Earning a masters degree in economics at NYU in the 1970s required the completion of 32 credits as well as a masters thesis. The thesis was usually written under the supervision of an advisor as the primary goal of a course entitled "Reading and Research in Economics." The Chairman of the Economics Department during the time these theses were produced was Dr. M. Ishaq Nadiri. Most of the theses are signed as having been approved by the students' faculty advisors. Some of these names can be found as access points.
The Department of Economics now offers undergraduate, masters, and doctoral degrees.
